title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Joe Biden raised concerns about China's “coercive” behaviour and human rights abuses with Xi Jinping, in the first call between the US and Chinese presidents since Biden entered office three weeks ago.

The White House said the two leaders spoke on Wednesday evening Washington time. It added that Biden offered well wishes to Xi for the lunar new year but also registered his unease over a range of issues.

Xi told Biden that “China-US confrontation will hurt both sides — co-operation is the only choice”, according to a summary of the call released by Chinese state television.

The call came hours after Biden announced the creation of a Pentagon task force to help craft a comprehensive strategy for dealing with China.

Separately, Department of Justice attorneys said in a court filing that they had begun to review whether TikTok, the Chinese-owned video app, was a threat to national security as the Trump administration had claimed. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell said America was still “very far from a strong labour market” and that inflation would remain subdued in a speech on Wednesday. US banks, meanwhile, are pressing the US central bank to extend concessions that loosened capital requirements when the pandemic struck.

  • AstraZeneca aims to cut the time needed to mass-produce a version of its Covid-19 vaccine adapted to new virus variants, it said today. The World Health Organization recommended the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine for worldwide use by all adults, including the elderly, on Wednesday.

  • The spread of new Covid strains has made it even more urgent to launch rapid vaccination programmes in poorer countries.

  • Tehran is struggling to convince Iranians to take Russia's Sputnik V jab. The west should heed Moscow and Beijing's use of vaccines to court poorer nations, writes Anne-Sylvaine Chassany.

  • Japan has suffered a rise in female suicides during the pandemic.

Follow the latest updates on our live blog and the global race to vaccinate on our tracker.

In the news

Exclusive: Microsoft approached Pinterest Microsoft approached Pinterest in recent months about a potential deal to acquire the $51bn social media company. Shares in Pinterest were up about 7 per cent in pre-market trade on Thursday morning. In other deal news, Kraft Heinz has agreed to sell its Planters peanuts and snacks business for $3.35bn. (FT)

Trump impeachment trial, day two Democrats pinned the blame for the deadly January 6 siege on the US Capitol squarely on Donald Trump, labelling the former president “inciter-in-chief”. Previously unseen footage of the attack was shown as the impeachment trial of the former US president kicked off in earnest in the Senate. (FT, AP)

Biden to impose sanctions on Myanmar's military leaders The White House will impose sanctions on the military leaders of the coup in Myanmar and freeze $1bn in government assets held in the US. Meanwhile, the military leadership in Myanmar has drafted a draconian cyber security bill as thousands continue to protest across the country. (FT)

Semiconductor shortage to hit GM earnings General Motors said that the global shortage of semiconductors would have a short-term impact on the company's earnings and cash this year, even as it reported profits for 2020. In other earnings news, the boost to Uber's food-delivery service from the pandemic could not offset declines in its bigger rideshare business. (FT)

US brokers' race to attract investors The era of commission-free trading has driven a relentless race to defend market share, fuelling a trading frenzy. That has empowered day traders but could be “distorting” their sense of risk, analysts say.

  • But Carson Block, founder of Muddy Waters Capital, says the primary causes of recent market dysfunction are the prevalence of passive investing and leverage. (FT)

Trading places Amsterdam surpassed London as Europe's largest share trading centre last month as the Netherlands scooped up business lost by the UK since Brexit. US-based Intercontinental Exchange said this week it would move the trading of EU carbon contracts from the UK capital to the Dutch city. (FT)

Renzi hails prospect of Draghi government According to one former Italian premier, Matteo Renzi is the most unpopular man in Italy. Yet the former prime minister is in triumphant mood when he talks to the FT. He insists the entry of former ECB president Mario Draghi into Italian politics would not have happened without him. (FT)

KPMG's UK boss steps aside KPMG UK chairman Bill Michael is stepping aside while the Big Four accountancy firm investigates “alleged comments” he made during an online meeting with staff, a spokesperson said. The Financial Times reported comments made by Michael to staff to “stop moaning” and “playing the victim card”. (FT)

The day ahead

Bumble shares debut Wall Street gave the online dating app Bumble a warm welcome on Wednesday, pricing its shares in an initial public offering above their marketed range and valuing the company at more than $8bn. Shares begin trading for the first time later today. (FT)

Earnings round-up Consumer goods companies Kraft Heinz and PepsiCo, which recently announced a joint venture with Beyond Meat, report results today. In the media sector Walt Disney, which has had tremendous success with its streaming service during the pandemic, also releases results. (FT)

Jobless claims data We also get the latest snapshot of the US employment market today when the weekly jobless claims data is released. Economists are expecting new claims to remain elevated at 758,000 for the week ending February 6, down from 779,000 the previous week. (FT)

UK-EU crunch talks Maros Sefcovic, EU vice-president, and Michael Gove meet in London on Thursday to address mounting concerns over the implementation of the Northern Ireland protocol. (FT)

Lunar new year Celebrations begin to mark the Year of the Ox. China's transport ministry forecasts a total of 1.15bn trips this year, compared with 3bn in 2019. (FT)

What else we're reading

Brazil's agricultural boom — at what cost? Brazil's far-western state of Mato Grosso has become one of the world's leading producers of a crop so lucrative locals call it “green gold”: soyabeans. The boom has been spurred by shifting geopolitics, from the rise of China to the arrival of populist leader Jair Bolsanaro. Bryan Harris, the FT's Brazil bureau chief, visits expansive frontier territory. (FT)

Nouriel Roubini: bitcoin is not a hedge against tail risk Elon Musk may be buying it, but that doesn't mean everyone else should follow suit, writes the professor of economics at NYU's Stern School of Business, predicting the bubble will end in another bust. Ark Investment Management's Cathie Wood said Musk's cryptocurrency move was typical of innovators. (FT)

Murdoch in the climate hot seat For all the anxiety about fake news on social media, climate disinformation seems to stem disproportionately from one old man using old media: Rupert Murdoch. The media magnate offers a platform to sceptical voices in Australia and stands accused of holding significant sway in this arena, Simon Kuper writes. (FT)

Silicon Valley should give every child a laptop This past year has exposed not only the cruelty of economic and social divides but also the vicious inequity of digital divides, writes Gillian Tett. Big Tech could step in to help fund laptops: they are swimming in cash and badly need to win public support. (FT)

How ‘design-thinking' can help lawyers do a better job Design-thinking is an approach that puts user experience at the heart of the creative process. By using the approach to make legal services more about people, Fiona Philips, global head of digital legal at HSBC, saw the potential to make the law more accessible and open to all. This is the latest in our Digital Lawyers Special Reports series. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Britain's post-Brexit role as ‘global broker' Gideon Rachman talks to Robin Niblett, director of the Chatham House think-tank, and economist Linda Yueh, currently a visiting professor at the London School of Economics, about Britain's future role on the world stage. (FT)
